title: Woodson Negro Makers of History - claim

content.description:
“This book is an adaptation of The Negro in Our History...[for] children in the elementary schools.... 
The aim here is to facilitate the teacher’s task of preparing children.... The teacher must hold up before them the examples of their own people, who have done things worth while. Those who have no record of what their forbears have accomplished lose the inspiration which comes from the teaching of biography and history. 
With these things in mind the author has not only presented the essentials of this history but also extensive sketches of those who have done these significant things. In almost every chapter, then, will be found the story of some prominent figure set forth as a maker of history.... 
The teacher...should [also] keep on hand certain important books for reference. The most useful for this course are Kerlin’s Negro Poets and Their Poems and the author’s Negro Orators and Their Orations. In these two works are found most of the best speeches and poems of the large majority of the characters treated in this book. Both teachers and pupils will be interested in extending their knowledge of these persons by reading their productions.”
Source: Carter G. Woodson, Preface of Negro Makers of History, Washington, D.C., September, 1928.
content.question: Which of the following best supports Woodson’s claim that children with "no record of what their forbears have accomplished lose the inspiration which comes from the teaching of biography and history”?

choices.label: Many African American scholars used art and literature to combat segregation and racial violence across the United States.
Many African American scholars believed that American schools reinforced the idea that Black people had made no contributions to society.
Many African American scholars advocated for the segregation of public education institutions as a means of teaching Black history more thoroughly.
Many African American scholars created artistic productions in an attempt to expand the teaching of Black history and culture.

content.answer: Many African American scholars believed that American schools reinforced the idea that Black people had made no contributions to society.
